metadata.case_name: Jai Kaur & Ors. v. Sher Singh & Anr.

facts.text: Suit instituted by respondents Sher Singh and Labh Singh for declaration that deed of gift executed by first appellant Jai Kaur of 8 1/10 Bighas of land inherited from her husband Dev Singh in favour of her two daughters (2nd and 3rd appellants) is null and void against reversionary rights of plaintiffs and defendants Nos. 4 to 6 after death of Jai Kaur.
Lands left by Dev Singh were ancestral lands qua the plaintiffs; according to customary law of Jats belonging to Grewal got, daughters do not succeed to property left by sonless fathers.

Alternative plea: Even if land non-ancestral qua plaintiffs, deed of gift null and void against reversionary interests as daughters do not succeed among Grewal Jats even as regards non-ancestral property.

Suit land was not ancestral qua plaintiffs and defendants Nos. 4 to 6; according to customary law, daughters exclude collaterals as regards non-ancestral property; widow competent to make gift to daughters.
Daughters being preferential heirs as against plaintiffs, gift tantamount to acceleration of succession and valid.

Trial Judge (Subordinate Judge, 1st Class, Ludhiana, Feb 6, 1948, Suit No. 918/1946) held 2B-2B,14-B ancestral, gift invalid as daughters do not succeed in presence of collaterals; remainder non-ancestral, gift acceleration of succession, valid; decree to plaintiffs for ancestral portion, dismissed for rest.

Plaintiffs appealed to District Judge, Ludhiana (Dec 20, 1948); cross-objections by defendants 1-3; finding on ancestral/non-ancestral not disputed; District Judge agreed daughters exclude collaterals for non-ancestral, gift acceleration valid; dismissed appeal and cross-objections.

Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 176/1949 (Judgment May 27, 1953) held special custom among Grewal Jats, daughter does not inherit even non-ancestral property; gift valid only during Jai Kaur's lifetime; allowed appeal.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court by defendants 1-3 (Jai Kaur and daughters).
Parties belong to Jats of Grewal got in Ludhiana governed by customary law.
House out of ancestral property not included in deed of gift.

legal_issues.text: Whether under customary law governing Jats of Grewal got in Ludhiana, daughter or collaterals are preferential heirs as regards non-ancestral property.
If daughters have preference over collaterals, whether gift is permissible acceleration of succession.

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit land not ancestral qua plaintiffs and def 4-6; daughters exclude collaterals re non-ancestral property; widow competent to gift such property to daughters.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Customary law; para 23 Rattigan's Digest (13th Ed.)

petitioner_arguments.text: Daughters preferential heirs, gift tantamount to acceleration of succession, valid.
Riwaj-i-am entries (Q43, 1882 settlement) do not cover non-ancestral property.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Precedents like Mst. Raj Kaur v. Talok Singh (AIR 1916 Lah 343); Full Bench Mt. Hurmate v. Hoshiaru (AIR 1944 Lah 21)

petitioner_arguments.text: Under s.14 Hindu Succession Act 1956, mother or daughters full owners.

respondent_arguments.text: Land ancestral qua plaintiffs; daughters do not succeed to sonless father's property under Grewal Jat custom.
Even if non-ancestral, daughters do not succeed; collaterals preferred.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Special custom per Riwaj-i-am Q43; precedents like Jatan v. Jiwan Singh (AIR 1933 Lah 553)

respondent_arguments.text: Mother ceased possession, daughters' possession not qualifying under s.14 HSA.

court_reasoning.text: Rattigan's Digest para 23 authoritative: daughters preferred to collaterals re non-ancestral (acquired) property under general Punjab custom.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Riwaj-i-am entries presume correctness but weak re females; here conflict, but Q43 refers only to ancestral property unless clear contrary indication.

court_reasoning.text: Reviewed Punjab cases: Early view (Raj Kaur, etc.) Riwaj-i-am re ancestral only; Jatan etc. contrary but overruled by Full Bench Mt. Hurmate: Q43 Ludhiana re ancestral only.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Full Bench view correct; tribesmen thought of ancestral; no indication Q43 covers non-ancestral.

court_reasoning.text: East Punjab HC in Mohinder Singh disregarded Full Bench improperly; Division Bench must follow Full Bench.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judicial decorum requires reference to larger bench if disagree.

court_reasoning.text: No oral evidence proves custom excluding daughters re non-ancestral; precedents like Jatan based on erroneous Riwaj-i-am interpretation, valueless.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Daughters preferred re non-ancestral per Rattigan.

court_reasoning.text: Gift not acceleration: Widow's surrender requires total effacement of entire interest in entire property; here partial (ancestral house excluded, gift to daughters re non-ancestral but not full reversioners re ancestral).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No partial effacement; no novel doctrine splitting ancestral/non-ancestral.

court_reasoning.text: Hindu Succession Act s.14 not applicable: No evidence adduced; possession issues unresolved; to be decided in future suit.

holdings.text: Customary law Grewal Jats Ludhiana: Daughters preferred to collaterals re non-ancestral property.
Deed of gift valid only during widow's lifetime, not beyond as against reversioners; not acceleration/surrender.

precedents_cited.relevance: Riwaj-i-am presumption weak where adversely affects females without opportunity to appear.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mst. Raj Kaur v. Talok Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Riwaj-i-am does not cover self-acquired; refers to ancestral.
Riwaj-i-am refers to ancestral unless clear contrary.
Held Q43 covers non-ancestral but based on erroneous assumption; valueless.
Interpreted Riwaj-i-am as covering non-ancestral; erroneous.
Full Bench: Q43 Ludhiana re ancestral only.
Surrender must be entire interest in entire property.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Succession Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned by counsel but not applied due to lack of evidence/pleadings.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court decree upheld declaring deed of gift null and void against reversioners after donor's lifetime, for both ancestral and non-ancestral portions.

key_quotes.text: "under the general customary law of the Punjab daughters exclude collaterals in succession to non-ancestral property."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Question No. 43 of the Customary Law of Ludhiana district relates to ancestral property only and can in no circumstances be so interpreted as to cover self acquired property as well."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Adopts Full Bench holding on Riwaj-i-am.

key_quotes.text: "a surrender by a limited owner to a reversioner, may be effective, the surrender must be of the entire interest of the limited owner in the entire property."
key_quotes.speaker: court
